Answer 1 : Itâ€™s personal. You have to find your own meaning. Any piece of wisdom anybody else gives you, whether itâ€™s Buddha or me, is going to sound like nonsense. Fundamentally, you have to find it for yourself, so the important part is not the answer, itâ€™s the question. You just have to sit there and dig with the question. It might take you years or decades. When you find an answer youâ€™re happy with, it will be fundamental to your life.

Answer 2 : There is no meaning to life. There is no purpose to life. Osho said, â€œItâ€™s like writing on water or building houses of sand.â€ The reality is youâ€™ve been dead for the history of the Universe, 10 billion years or more. You will be dead for the next 70 billion years or so, until the heat death of the Universe.

Anything you do will fade. It will disappear, just like the human race will disappear and the planet will disappear. Even the group who colonizes Mars will disappear. No one is going to remember you past a certain number of generations, whether youâ€™re an artist, a poet, a conqueror, a pauper, or anyone else. Thereâ€™s no meaning.

These are all meanings you make up.

There is no fundamental, intrinsic purposeful meaning to the Universe. If there was, then you would just ask the next question. Youâ€™d say, â€œWhy is that the meaning?â€ It would be, as physicist Richard Feynman said, it would be â€œturtles all the way down.â€ The â€œwhyâ€™sâ€ would keep accumulating. There is no answer you could give that wouldnâ€™t have another â€œwhy.â€

I donâ€™t buy the everlasting afterlife answers because itâ€™s insane to me, with absolutely no evidence, to believe because of how you live seventy years here on this planet, youâ€™re going to spend eternity, which is a very long time, in some afterlife. What kind of silly God judges you for eternity based on some small period of time here? I think after this life, itâ€™s very much like before you were born. Remember that? Itâ€™s going to be just like that.

Answer 3 : The last answer Iâ€™ll give you is a little more complicated. From what Iâ€™ve read in science (friends of mine have written books on this), Iâ€™ve stitched together some theories. Maybe there is a meaning to life, but itâ€™s not a very satisfying purpose.

ç­”æ¡ˆ3ï¼šæˆ‘è¦ç»™ä½ çš„æœ€åä¸€ä¸ªç­”æ¡ˆæœ‰ç‚¹å¤æ‚ã€‚æ ¹æ®æˆ‘åœ¨ç§‘å­¦ä¸Šè¯»åˆ°çš„ä¸œè¥¿(æˆ‘çš„æœ‹å‹å†™è¿‡å…³äºè¿™æ–¹é¢çš„ä¹¦)ï¼Œæˆ‘æ‹¼å‡‘äº†ä¸€äº›ç†è®ºã€‚ä¹Ÿè®¸ç”Ÿå‘½æ˜¯æœ‰æ„ä¹‰çš„ï¼Œä½†å®ƒä¸æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªéå¸¸ä»¤äººæ»¡æ„çš„ç›®æ ‡ã€‚

Basically, in physics, the arrow of time comes from entropy. The second law of thermodynamics states entropy only goes up, which means disorder in the Universe only goes up, which means concentrated free energy only goes down. If you look at living things (humans, plants, civilizations, what have you) these systems are locally reversing entropy. Humans locally reverse entropy because we have action.

åŸºæœ¬ä¸Šï¼Œåœ¨ç‰©ç†å­¦ä¸­ï¼Œæ—¶é—´ä¹‹ç®­æ¥è‡ªç†µã€‚çƒ­åŠ›å­¦ç¬¬äºŒå®šå¾‹è§„å®šç†µåªä¼šä¸Šå‡ï¼Œè¿™æ„å‘³ç€å®‡å®™ä¸­çš„æ— åºåªä¼šä¸Šå‡ï¼Œè¿™æ„å‘³ç€é›†ä¸­çš„è‡ªç”±èƒ½åªä¼šä¸‹é™ã€‚å¦‚æœä½ è§‚å¯Ÿç”Ÿç‰©(äººç±»ã€æ¤ç‰©ã€æ–‡æ˜ï¼Œä½ æœ‰ä»€ä¹ˆ)ï¼Œè¿™äº›ç³»ç»Ÿæ­£åœ¨å±€éƒ¨é€†è½¬ç†µã€‚äººç±»å±€éƒ¨é€†è½¬ç†µæ˜¯å› ä¸ºæˆ‘ä»¬æœ‰è¡ŒåŠ¨ã€‚

In the process, we globally accelerate entropy until the heat death of the Universe. You could come up with some fanciful theory, which I like, that weâ€™re headed towards the heat death of the Universe. In that death, thereâ€™s no concentrated energy, and everything is at the same energy level. Therefore, weâ€™re all one thing. Weâ€™re essentially indistinguishable.

What we do as living systems accelerates getting to that state. The more complex system you create, whether itâ€™s through computers, civilization, art, mathematics, or creating a familyâ€”you actually accelerate the heat death of the Universe. Youâ€™re pushing us towards this point where we end up as one thing. [4]
